revised_title: Parasite Effects on Mate Choice Decisions in Female Upland Bullies
tldr: The study examines how parasitic infections affect mate choice decisions in female upland bullies. Heavily parasitized females were found to make fewer mate inspections and were more likely to choose lower-quality mates than lightly parasitized females. This discovery suggests that parasites may have a negative impact on female choosiness, potentially limiting the role of parasites in sexual selection and the evolution of male secondary sexual traits.
